author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Start Planning Your Picnics With This Wine and Cheese Tote
description: The insulated bag also comes with a cutting board, a cheese knife and a wine opener.
content: It’s not quite picnic season, but we’re getting close. Here’s an accessory to consider for al fresco excursions, a tote not just for wine but also for cheese. Made of utilitarian khaki canvas with brown leatherette trim, it has an insulated interior with the capacity for two bottles of wine and some cheese, several outside pockets and a shoulder strap. It comes with a wooden cutting board, a cheese knife and a waiter’s corkscrew, but no glassware or dishes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marlise Simons
title: Ukraine takes its case against Russia to the U.N.’s highest court.
description: The head of the Ukrainian delegation told the court that “millions are in danger” and accused Moscow of defiling the Genocide Convention.
content: Ukraine turned to the United Nations’ highest court on Monday to try to stop Russia’s invasion, urging its judges to issue an injunction demanding that Russia end its violent incursion in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: A funding dispute with G.O.P. senators may complicate Biden’s efforts on antivirals and tests.
description: A funding dispute with Republican senators may complicate the Biden administration’s efforts to guarantee supplies of free antiviral pills and monoclonal antibody treatments this year to Americans who test positive for the coronavirus.
content: A funding dispute with Republican senators may complicate the Biden administration’s efforts to guarantee supplies of free antiviral pills and monoclonal antibody treatments this year to Americans who test positive for the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Selin Davis
title: Can We Empathize With Our Enemies? One Author Wants Us to Try.
description: Mónica Guzmán’s new book, “I Never Thought of It That Way,” examines our polarized culture and helps us find common ground.
content: I NEVER THOUGHT OF IT THAT WAYHow to Have Fearlessly Curious Conversations in Dangerously Divided TimesBy Mónica Guzmán
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: The Flea Theater, Experimenting Again, Walks a New Tightrope
description: Back from the brink of extinction, the Off Off Broadway fixture is testing a new structure that gives artists the autonomy they demanded.
content: Since its inception in the mid-1990s, the Flea Theater has positioned itself as a haven for experimentation, an unpretentious home for risk-taking and for young actors eager to get their start.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: An agreement on nuclear plants in Ukraine is urgently needed, the U.N. nuclear agency says.
description: There has been no release of radiation, but problems have arisen at plants, said Rafael Mariano Grossi, the head of the International Atomic Energy Agency.
content: Concerns are rising over the operations of nuclear power plants in Ukraine without concrete agreements between Russia and Ukraine on safety and security, the head of the International Atomic Energy Agency said on Monday, adding that his agency, the nuclear watchdog of the United Nations, was working urgently to facilitate a meeting with the two parties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: ‘Putin Will Not Lose. He’s Not Going to Let That Happen.’
description: Whether the Russian leader wins this war or loses it, Europe is in trouble.
content: On Friday, the Kremlin blocked access to Facebook inside Russia and passed a law making it illegal to spread what the government determines to be “false information” about the country’s armed forces. It was the latest move in President Vladimir Putin’s crackdown on dissent, which may be working. TikTok announced on Sunday that it is suspending livestreaming and new posts from Russia in response to the new disinformation law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Allows Court-Imposed Voting Maps in North Carolina and Pennsylvania
description: State courts had ruled that earlier maps for congressional elections had been warped by partisan gerrymandering. Democrats stand to benefit from the justices’ decision.
content: The Supreme Court on Monday allowed congressional maps that had been approved by state courts in North Carolina and Pennsylvania to stand, giving Democrats an advantage in this year’s election in two key states.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Murray
title: Amy Coney Barrett Was a Supermom. So Is Ketanji Brown Jackson.
description: Republicans celebrated Amy Coney Barrett’s role at home. Democrats should do the same for Ketanji Brown Jackson.
content: Much has been made in recent days of the racial and gender diversity that President Biden’s choice of Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson would add to the Supreme Court. But there has been surprisingly little discussion of the fact that she would join Justice Amy Coney Barrett as the court’s second working mother.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William P. Davis and Stanley Reed
title: Stocks extend their rout as the Ukraine war and its economic fallout intensify.
description: The S&P 500’s drop was its sharpest since October 2020. The tech-heavy Nasdaq composite is down 20 percent from its November record.
content: Global stocks slid and energy prices jumped on Monday as attacks on Ukraine escalated and governments considered ever-stricter economic penalties on Russia, including cutting off imports of Russian oil. It was Wall Street’s worst day in more than a year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz
title: Ukrainian forces have repelled another Russian assault on Mykolaiv, officials say.
description: As the opposing armies fought outside the strategic port city near the Black Sea, residential areas within Mykolaiv came under intensifying Russian rocket and artillery fire.
content: MYKOLAIV, Ukraine — A day after Ukrainian forces pushed Russian troops back beyond the city limits of Mykolaiv, the Russians on Monday unleashed a ferocious artillery attack on the southern Ukrainian city, hitting residential neighborhoods with rockets and sending streams of people fleeing for safety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: The letter ‘Z’ has become a symbol for Russians who support the invasion of Ukraine.
description: The letter, painted on Russian military vehicles, is suddenly ubiquitous in Russia, prompting talk of a Kremlin public relations campaign.
content: The “Z” first drew attention several weeks ago when it was painted a couple feet high on the sides of the thousands of tanks, armored personnel carriers and other military vehicles mustering along the Russian border with Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Why China Can’t Bail Out Putin’s Economy
description: No, the Chinese can’t protect Russia from sanctions.
content: In deciding to invade Ukraine, Vladimir Putin clearly misjudged everything. He had an exaggerated view of his own nation’s military might; my description last week of Russia as a Potemkin superpower, with far less strength than meets the eye, looks even truer now. He vastly underrated Ukrainian morale and military prowess, and failed to anticipate the resolve of democratic governments — especially, although not only, the Biden administration, which, in case you haven’t noticed, has done a remarkable job on everything from arming Ukraine to rallying the West around financial sanctions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Queen Elizabeth holds her first face-to-face meeting after she had Covid.
description: The queen received Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada at Windsor Castle on Monday.
content: Queen Elizabeth II met Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada on Monday in her first in-person official meeting after testing positive for the coronavirus last month, giving further reassurance about her recovery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz and Nadia Shira Cohen
title: Italian City Tied to Russia by a Revered Saint Feels the Sting of War in Ukraine
description: The port of Bari holds relics venerated by Orthodox Christians throughout the former Soviet bloc. Today it is also home to a spillover of tensions from Russia’s invasion.
content: BARI, Italy — As the Orthodox chants in Russian and the Ukrainian bishop’s voice echoed in the ancient crypt, the faithful lowered their scarf-wrapped heads to the marble floor, held candles over their Cyrillic prayer books or wept under low stone arches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: What to Do With Spring’s Wild Joy in a Burning World
description: In this troubled time, it would be a crime to snuff out any flicker of joy that somehow leaps into life.
content: March comes in like a lion, except when it comes in like a lamb. Or when it comes in like a chorus, a symphony and an exquisitely choreographed ballet all at once, a performance so breathtaking, it could not possibly be replicated and yet is replicated anyway, day after day after day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Lynsea Garrison, Sydney Harper, Kaitlin Roberts, Mike Benoist, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: On the Road With Ukraine’s Refugees
description: We report alongside Ukrainians making their escape from Russia’s increasingly brutal invasion.
content: This episode contains strong language.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Simonson
title: Manhatta to Reopen With a Focus on Drinks
description: Danny Meyer’s 60th-floor restaurant, which closed at the start of the pandemic, will return on St. Patrick’s Day.
content: Manhatta, the sky-high restaurant that the restaurateur Danny Meyer closed at the beginning of the pandemic, will reopen on March 17. But the sprawling space on the 60th floor of 28 Liberty Street in the financial district, with its breathtaking views of the city, will serve only drinks and bar food, at least at first.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: E.P.A. to Tighten Tailpipe Rules for the Biggest Polluters on the Road
description: For the first time since 2001, the government is setting more stringent limits on pollution from trucks, vans, and buses that harms human health.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration on Monday proposed strict new limits on pollution from buses, delivery vans, tractor-trailers and other heavy trucks — the first time in more than 20 years that tailpipe standards have been tightened for the biggest polluters on the road.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: In a First, California Plans to Clean Up Microplastics
description: The state has adopted a strategy to monitor and reduce the ubiquitous form of pollution.
content: They are in your gut. They are in the ocean. They are even floating through the air in the most remote regions of the West. Microplastics — fragments of broken-down plastic no larger than a fraction of an inch — have become a colossal global problem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Porter
title: Employer Practices Limit Workers’ Choices and Wages, U.S. Study Argues
description: A Biden administration report says collusion and other constraints on competition hold down pay and prospects in the labor market.
content: The recent narrative is that there is a tight labor market that gives workers leverage. But a new report from the Biden administration argues that the deck is still stacked against workers, reducing their ability to move from one employer to another and hurting their pay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: War in Ukraine Rallies Support in Congress for More Military Spending
description: A bipartisan consensus in Congress to increase the Pentagon’s budget is growing stronger as Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has created a sense of insecurity.
content: WASHINGTON — From his perch as chairman of the Armed Services Committee, Representative Adam Smith, Democrat of Washington, has long lamented what he sees as a Pentagon budget bloated by inefficient spending. When hawkish lawmakers led a successful charge last year to pour nearly $24 billion more into the military’s coffers, he opposed the move.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: Rents Are Roaring Back in New York City
description: While rents plunged at the start of the pandemic, they are now surging, and the increase is double the national rate, amplifying the city’s affordability crisis.
content: Gabbie Fried, an actor and comedy writer, had lived in New York City for 10 years and had never been able to afford her own place. Then, last February, she found a one-bedroom apartment she liked on the Upper West Side. At $1,945 per month, it was tantalizingly close to her price range — she moved in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Contradicting federal guidance, Florida will recommend against Covid vaccines for healthy children.
description: The C.D.C. has urged parents to get their eligible children vaccinated. “Covid-19 can make children very sick and cause children to be hospitalized,” the agency’s website says.
content: Contradicting guidance from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Florida will soon recommend that healthy children not get vaccinated against Covid-19, the state’s surgeon general, Dr. Joseph A. Ladapo, announced on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kayla Stewart and Clay Williams
title: One Huge Hog, One Long Day and a Nourishing Southern Tradition
description: At his farm in South Carolina, Marvin Ross is carrying on the ritual of hog slaughters, a disappearing staple of Black agrarian life.
content: RIDGEVILLE, S.C. — It was 37 degrees at 4 a.m. in this small town about a 40-minute drive northwest of Charleston. Under a black February sky, a few men gathered logs to start a fire in a wooded backyard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle and Michael Gonchar
title: What Sports Deserve More Hype?
description: Pickleball, a mash-up of tennis, badminton and Ping-Pong, has been growing in popularity. What other sports should be more appreciated?
content: Have you ever heard of pickleball? It’s a sport that was invented more than 50 years ago and that has become a favorite with retirees and some celebrities in the past decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Sweet-Savory Hamantaschen Perfect for Purim
description: The mother-daughter baking team Birdie’s Batch in West Nyack, N.Y., make a goat cheese and quince paste version, among others.
content: For years, bakers have riffed on the recipe for hamantaschen, the traditional sweet for Purim, which starts at sunset on March 16 this year. A newcomer to the game is Birdie’s Batch in West Nyack, N.Y., a home-based, licensed company that got started during the pandemic. Virginia and Sara Cann, the mother-and-daughter team behind the enterprise have come up with a sweet-savory goat cheese and membrillo (quince paste) hamantaschen, enclosed in a tender, golden pastry triangle. (The recipe has been tweaked since they started selling the treats last year.) “We had been making membrillo and it wasn’t selling all that well,” said Sara, the daughter. “So we decided to try something different.” They’re sold in lots of six for $15. Other flavors are blueberry and peach jam, two of the preserves that are their specialty. There is also a handsome, rich 9-inch Guinness chocolate cake with an espresso glaze ($25) that could ennoble the St. Patrick’s Day table. Their products are sold at Hudson Valley farmers’ markets and can be ordered to ship within New York State.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi
title: Dreaming of Suitcases in Space
description: A California start-up company believes it can one day speed delivery of important items by storing them in orbit.
content: LAKE ELSINORE, Calif. — The mission to turn space into the next frontier for express deliveries took off from a modest propeller plane above a remote airstrip in the shadow of the Santa Ana mountains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard L. Hasen
title: How to Keep the Rising Tide of Fake News From Drowning Our Democracy
description: It won’t be easy, but our democracy depends on it.
content: The same information revolution that brought us Netflix, podcasts and the knowledge of the world in our smartphone-gripping hands has also undermined American democracy. There can be no doubt that virally spread political disinformation and delusional invective about stolen, rigged elections are threatening the foundation of our Republic. It’s going to take both legal and political change to bolster that foundation, and it might not be enough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Whet Moser
title: Coronavirus Briefing: Risks to the brain
description: Covid-19 may cause  tissue damage and loss of gray matter
content: Covid-19 may cause greater loss of gray matter and tissue damage in the brain than naturally occurs in people who have not been infected with the virus, a large new study finds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: Congress moves to bar Russian energy imports and end favorable trade relations.
description: A bipartisan group of lawmakers reached an agreement on legislation that, if passed, would bar imports of Russian energy and suspend normal trade relations with Russia and Belarus.
content: A bipartisan group of lawmakers said on Monday that they would move forward with legislation that would ban imports of Russian energy into the United States and suspend normal trade relations with Russia and Belarus in response to the invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: This Greek Olive Vodka Calls for a Martini
description: Kástra Elión is distilled from wheat and a mixture of olives hand-picked in Nafpaktos, Greece.
content: Kástra Elión, Greek olive vodka, makes for elegant sipping with a modicum of richness. Don’t skip the olives in a martini; the taste delivers but a whiff of the flavoring. The vodka is distilled from wheat and a mixture of olives hand-picked in Nafpaktos, a town defined by a castle, the Kástra of the name. (Elión is a derivative of the word “olive.”) It comes in a lovely glass bottle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Daniel Radcliffe to Star in Off Broadway ‘Merrily’ Revival
description: A new production of Stephen Sondheim’s “Merrily We Roll Along” is to be staged late this year by the nonprofit New York Theater Workshop in the East Village.
content: The actor Daniel Radcliffe will star in an Off Broadway revival of “Merrily We Roll Along,” a Stephen Sondheim musical that famously flopped on Broadway but in the decades since has become an oft-produced and beloved show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport, Edward Wong and Michael D. Shear
title: U.S. Weighs Russian Oil Ban as Gas Prices Surge and Ukraine War Grows
description: Global stocks dipped on Monday as U.S. officials discussed an oil cutoff, and gas prices hit a national average above $4, up more than 10 percent in a week.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden came under pressure on Monday to ban Russian oil imports into the United States, forcing the administration to consider action that could further punish President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia but exacerbate high gas prices that are hurting consumers at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: ‘20th Hijacker’ Is Returned to Saudi Arabia for Mental Health Care
description: Mohammed al-Qahtani had spent 20 years at Guantánamo Bay, where he was tortured so badly that he was ineligible to be tried at the war crimes court.
content: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — The Biden administration on Monday repatriated to Saudi Arabia for mental health care a prisoner who had been tortured so badly by U.S. interrogators that he was ruled ineligible for trial as the suspected would-be 20th hijacker in the Sept. 11 attacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Laetitia Vancon
title: Once Victims in Southeast Europe, Jews Come to Aid Fleeing Ukrainians
description: Today, as in the early 1900s, Jews are once again escaping violence in southeast Europe. But the context is radically different — cathartically so for the many Israelis who have come here to join the relief effort.
content: CHISINAU, Moldova — At a synagogue in central Chisinau on Monday, an Israeli social worker, Omer Hod, had a flash of historical vertigo. Ms. Hod’s ancestors had lived in Chisinau more than a century ago, surviving a devastating pogrom in 1903 before emigrating to what became Israel. Now their descendant had returned to the Moldovan capital — this time not as a victim, but as a rescuer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: This Price Surge Really Hits New Yorkers Hard
description: Rents are spiking in the city, especially in wealthier neighborhoods, where they have gone up by 40 percent.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll look at another sign that New York City is returning to its prepandemic ways — rents on apartments are rising again. We’ll also meet “the most influential New Yorker you’ve never heard of.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Car Industry Woes Show How Global Conflicts Will Reshape Trade
description: The war in Ukraine has highlighted the risks of doing business with authoritarian countries — not just Russia, but also China.
content: The auto assembly lines going quiet in Germany, Britain and Austria are more than just another example of how fragile supply chains have become. The shutdowns may foreshadow a fundamental reordering of the global economy that Russia’s invasion of Ukraine will accelerate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo and Adam Bednar
title: Truckers demonstrate outside Washington for a second day.
description: Organizers of a convoy of vehicles protesting mask and vaccine mandates said they would drive another lap around the Beltway on Monday but did not intend to enter the capital.
content: A convoy of truckers and other supporters circled the capital on the Beltway for a second day on Monday, protesting Covid-19 mandates and hoping to attract attention from lawmakers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Fleeing Civilians Under Fire
description: Fears are growing for Ukrainians trapped in besieged cities.
content: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany
title: Oil Prices Jump as U.S. Discusses Russian Import Ban
description: The cost of Brent crude, the international benchmark, was trading at about $129 a barrel on Monday.
content: The price of oil has jumped again as the United States considers an embargo on Russian imports in response to the war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat and Zach Montague
title: Armed Intruder Prompts Lockdown at Joint Base Andrews as Vice President Lands
description: A 17-year-old was arrested and a second intruder got away after they drove through a checkpoint, the authorities said. Vice President Kamala Harris had just landed at the base.
content: A 17-year-old was arrested and another person got away after they drove through a checkpoint at the military base in Maryland that the president and the vice president use to travel to and from Washington, military officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Callahan
title: Will One Moldy Berry Ruin the Rest?
description: Here’s what the experts say.
content: Q: If I open a box of berries and one berry is moldy, do I need to throw out the whole box?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Their Time Served, Sex Offenders Are Kept in Prison in ‘Cruel Catch-22’
description: New York prisons will not release people convicted of some sex offenses until they find housing far from schools. But that is hard to do, especially from behind bars.
content: WASHINGTON — Angel Ortiz, in prison for robbery and attempted sexual abuse, had done his time. But before he could go free, a judge wrote, he faced “an unwinnable game of real-estate Battleship.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Again and Again, Literature Provides an Outlet for the Upended Lives of Refugees
description: The current flood of refugees from Ukraine is a reminder of how much of literature is fueled by such crises and their aftermaths.
content: Pursued by the armies of Vladimir Putin, a shark for all seasons, refugees are pouring through Europe at a rate not seen since World War II, according to the United Nations. It’s rarely seemed truer, as Don DeLillo wrote in “Zero K,” his 2016 novel, that “half the world is redoing its kitchens; the other half is starving.” The starving half, as often as not, is on the run.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: As the N.B.A. Turns, the Phoenix Suns Keep Chugging Along
description: The uncertainty surrounding the Lakers and interpersonal dramas among the Sixers, Nets and others have obscured the Suns’ steady pursuit of the N.B.A.’s best record.
content: Think about how the N.B.A. is consumed these days. Think about what draws buzz and eyeballs, and social media clicks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Varenikova
title: Hate for Putin’s Russia Consumes Ukraine
description: Much of the bitterness is directed at President Vladimir V. Putin, but Ukrainians also chastise ordinary Russians, calling them complicit.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — Trapped in his apartment on the outskirts of Kyiv during fierce battles over the weekend, the well-known Ukrainian poet Oleksandr Irvanets composed a few lines that encapsulated the national mood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Zernike
title: States Aren’t Waiting for the Supreme Court to Tighten Abortion Laws
description: In anticipation of the court’s decision, a frenzy of legislative activity to shut down access to abortion forms a picture of a post-Roe America.
content: Both sides of the abortion debate anticipate that come July, the Supreme Court will have overturned Roe v. Wade and with it the constitutional right to abortion, handing anti-abortion activists a victory they have sought for five decades. But from Florida to Idaho, Republican-led state legislatures are not waiting: They are operating as if Roe has already been struck down, advancing new restrictions that aim to make abortion illegal in as many circumstances as possible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Live Webinar: Teaching With ‘Black History, Continued’
description: Join us on March 24 as Veronica Chambers discusses the “Black History, Continued” series and the continuing importance of exploring pivotal moments and transformative figures in Black history.
content: “Black History, Continued” is an ongoing series from The New York Times that explores pivotal moments and transformative figures in Black culture and examines how the past shapes the present and the future. “We believe the story part of Black History is vital because, like elements in a periodic table, each story is a building block of possibility,” Veronica Chambers, the Narrative Projects editor, writes in announcing the series.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Back Slaps and Buzz Drown Out Critics at N.F.L. Combine
description: Even as agents and players questioned the inequities and value of the event, N.F.L. decision makers and, for the first time, fans, gathered again in Indianapolis.
content: INDIANAPOLIS — The first-year head coach of the Miami Dolphins, Mike McDaniel, stood off to the side of the stage at the Indiana Convention Center while his former boss, San Francisco 49ers General Manager John Lynch, responded to a reporter who had asked how he thought McDaniel would fare in his new post.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Cooking Competition for Julia Child Disciples
description: For “The Julia Child Challenge,” on the Food Network and Discovery+, eight competitors will prepare the chef’s classic recipes.
content: Reality TV in Julia Child’s name, and with the approval of the Julia Child Foundation for Gastronomy and the Culinary Arts, starts Monday, March 14, with “The Julia Child Challenge” on the Food Network (streaming on Discovery+). The last of eight cooks still stirring the pot after six episodes will receive an all-expenses paid trip to Paris to attend Le Cordon Bleu, the school where Ms. Child learned to whip egg whites and what to do when you drop the chicken on the floor. Each week on a set designed to replicate Ms. Child’s pegboard-lined kitchen in Cambridge, Mass. — now in the Smithsonian — the competitors from several states must prepare a dish for which Ms. Child is known, starting with sole meunière. They also have to make a dish of their own. Three judges, led by the chef Antonia Lofaso, will select a weekly winner, and one competitor will be voted out of the kitchen. This routine starts again the following week until the prizewinner is named in the final episode.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for Teapots
description: Because a beautiful teapot makes drinking tea even better.
content: Enjoying a cup of tea is as much about slowing down and appreciating the ritual as it is about having a hot drink. So your teapot should be an object you look forward to using every day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Becky Ferreira
title: Does This Amazon Rock Art Depict Extinct Ice Age Mammals?
description: The animals painted in ocher in Colombia may include giant ground sloths and other creatures that vanished from the Americas. But some researchers say the art has a more recent origin.
content: At the end of the last ice age, South America was home to strange animals that have since vanished into extinction: giant ground sloths, elephant-like herbivores and an ancient lineage of horses. A new study suggests that we can see these lost creatures in enchanting ocher paintings made by ice age humans on a rocky outcrop in the Colombian Amazon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Miss the Carnegie Deli? Murray’s Cheese Shop Has You Covered.
description: The cheese shop now sells the shuttered restaurant’s meats and its cinnamon and chocolate babkas.
content: The Carnegie Deli, a New York legend that opened in 1937 and closed in 2016, has been shipping its corned beef, pastrami and some other items from its bakery. Now, Murray’s Cheese Shop has picked up the baton and is selling the meats and the restaurant’s cinnamon and chocolate babkas in its three retail stores and online for shipping. Meats come in sliced 12-ounce portions ready to warm up for two sandwiches (enough for one sandwich if you’re a fresser like Mel Brooks).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: N.F.L. Hands Calvin Ridley a 1-Year Suspension for Betting on Games
description: The league said that Ridley, a receiver for the Atlanta Falcons, bet on games in November 2021 while he was on leave from the team to address a mental health issue.
content: Atlanta Falcons receiver Calvin Ridley was suspended for at least the entire 2022 season for gambling on N.F.L. games last year, one of the harshest penalties a major American sports league has doled out since the N.F.L. rushed to embrace an expansion of legalized wagering on games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘How a National Movement Toppled Hundreds of Confederate Symbols’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about the Confederate symbols that have been removed in a national racial reckoning since the murder of George Floyd. Then, they will design a memorial that honors an important figure in their community.
content: Featured Article: “How a National Movement Toppled Hundreds of Confederate Symbols” by Audra D. S. Burch
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz
title: Proud Band of Ukrainian Troops Holds Russian Assault at Bay — for Now
description: “Few expected such strength from our people,” said a Ukrainian colonel whose soldiers have repelled a Russian attack on the port city of Mykolaiv for three days.
content: MYKOLAIV, Ukraine — The remains of a Russian Tigr fighting vehicle sat smoldering on the side of the road, as Ukrainian troops lounged outside their trenches smoking cigarettes. Nearby, a group of local villagers was tinkering with a captured T-90 tank, trying to get it running again so that the Ukrainian Army might put it to use.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Metropolitan Opera Will Host Concert in Support of Ukraine
description: “We want Putin to know he is the enemy of artists and that we are united against his horrific actions,” the company’s general manager said.
content: The Metropolitan Opera said Monday that it would stage a concert in support of Ukraine next week in an effort to show solidarity with Ukrainians under attack, raise relief funds and express opposition to the invasion ordered by President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: With ‘Turning Red,’ a Big Red Panda Helps Break a Glass Ceiling
description: Domee Shi is the first woman filmmaker with sole directing credit on a Pixar feature.
content: Pixar has a well-deserved reputation for dudes — movies focused on dudes (20 out of 24 feature films), movies directed by dudes (23 of 24), movies written by dudes (50 of 59 screenwriters). But the Disney-owned animation studio has been trying to evolve, largely because many of its own artists have demanded it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: The pandemic’s official global toll surpasses 6 million known virus deaths.
description: And stark vaccination disparities between countries remain, leaving the entire world vulnerable to the threat of a new, deadly variant.
content: Though many global coronavirus trends are rapidly improving as countries emerge from surges driven by the highly transmissible Omicron variant, the grimmest metric hit a tragic milestone on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Preventing This War
description: What might have done it?
content: Was there any way to prevent the horrific war in Ukraine? Recent history offers at least a partial answer, and it’s one that is also relevant to the future of global stability.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Williamson
title: Alex Jones and Donald Trump: A Fateful Alliance Draws Scrutiny
description: The Infowars host tormented Sandy Hook families and helped elect President Donald J. Trump. His role in the Jan. 6 Capitol attack is now of growing interest to congressional investigators.
content: WASHINGTON — The day President Donald J. Trump urged his supporters to “be there, will be wild!” at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, Alex Jones spread the message to millions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Axios Wants Us to Read Everything in Bullet Points
description: The news organization that prides itself on short-format writing has big plans to expand in local news, paid newsletters and even the emails sent by your bosses.
content: With much of the digital media world combining forces to survive, the founders of five-year-old Axios think they have the right recipe for success on their own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘The Thing About Pam’ and the Critics Choice Awards
description: Renée Zellweger stars in a new true-crime mini-series. And this year’s Critics Choice Awards ceremony airs on the CW and TBS.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, March 7 -13. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley and Steven Lee Myers
title: ‘No Wavering’: After Turning to Putin, Xi Faces Hard Wartime Choices for China
description: Beijing aligned itself with Putin as Russia prepared to invade Ukraine. Now its efforts to edge away are constrained by leadership politics.
content: On a frigid day in Beijing last month as the Winter Olympics were set to open, China’s leader, Xi Jinping, celebrated a diplomatic triumph with a banquet for his honored guest, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia. They had just finalized a statement declaring their vision of a new international order with Moscow and Beijing at its core, untethered from American power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: Covid May Cause Changes in the Brain, New Study Finds
description: Brain scans before and after infection showed more loss of gray matter and tissue damage, mostly in areas related to smell, in people who had Covid than in those who did not.
content: Covid-19 may cause greater loss of gray matter and tissue damage in the brain than naturally occurs in people who have not been infected with the virus, a large new study found.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: Amazon Is Less Able to Recover From Droughts and Logging, Study Finds
description: The region is nearing a threshold beyond which its forests may be replaced by grasslands, with huge repercussions for biodiversity and climate change.
content: The Amazon is losing its ability to recover from disturbances like droughts and land-use changes, scientists reported Monday, adding to concern that the rainforest is approaching a critical threshold beyond which much of it will be replaced by grassland, with vast consequences for biodiversity and climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Camp
title: I Came to College Eager to Debate. I Found Self-Censorship Instead.
description: When we censor ourselves, our learning environments suffer.
content: Each week, I seek out the office hours of a philosophy department professor willing to discuss with me complex ethical questions raised by her course on gender and sexuality. We keep our voices lowered, as if someone might overhear us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Scottie Scheffler Plays It Straight to Win Arnold Palmer Invitational
description: One of golf’s hottest players, Scheffler won his second PGA Tour event of the year and rose to the top of the FedEx Cup standings.
content: ORLANDO, Fla. — Throughout the final round Sunday at the Arnold Palmer Invitational, it was as if someone were playing a prank on the world’s best golfers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Ukraine’s Paralympians Are ‘All Thinking of Home’
description: Some members of Ukraine’s delegation at the Beijing Paralympics described their emotional exhaustion and the toll of their isolation.
content: ZHANGJIAKOU, China — Valerii Sushkevych, the president of Ukraine’s Paralympic committee, can detect in the pink, swollen eyes of his athletes that they have not been sleeping.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Nocera
title: Take a closer look at why American mask makers are going out of business.
description: Back in 2005, when low-cost Chinese manufacturers were taking over the personal protective equipment industry, Mike Bowen joined a friend who had started a small surgical-mask company called Prestige Ameritech. The plan was to market his company’s masks to American hospitals and distributors as a way to provide resilience — a means of ensuring domestic supply, if the global supply chain ever faltered.
content: Back in 2005, when low-cost Chinese manufacturers were taking over the personal protective equipment industry, Mike Bowen joined a friend who had started a small surgical-mask company called Prestige Ameritech. The plan was to market his company’s masks to American hospitals and distributors as a way to provide resilience — a means of ensuring domestic supply, if the global supply chain ever faltered.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: A Plea for Protection, but Wary of the Law
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, March 7, 2022.
content: “We don’t care about your social experiment. We need our safety back.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: Fighting Disinformation Can Feel Like a Lost Cause. It Isn’t.
description: The right lessons can teach us all how to spot it.
content: A couple of weeks ago, I wrote about disinformation and how it has been used as a cudgel to dismiss and silence opinions that some people might not like. This doesn’t mean that disinformation isn’t a problem — the speed with which unverified, mislabeled or outright false news came out of Ukraine was a grim reminder of this — but it’s become increasingly difficult to tell the difference between what’s a purposeful attempt to mislead the public and what’s being called disinformation because of a genuine difference of opinion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lam Thuy Vo
title: How My Multilingual Upbringing Helps Me Solve Spelling Bee
description: A “woefully confused polyglot” discovers which non-English words have become common enough to count toward her Spelling Bee score.
content: As a child born to Vietnamese immigrants in Germany, I was sometimes asked to translate documents into German, some of which were much more important than I had realized. Growing up in this kind of household also meant being somewhat linguistically agile. From an early age, I made acrobatic leaps between grammatically and tonally disparate languages without thinking much about it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier and Jasmina Nielsen
title: These Refugees Can’t Stay in Denmark, but They Can’t Be Sent Home
description: Dozens of Syrian asylum seekers are stuck in limbo after the Danish authorities decided it was safe for them to go back home and stripped their residency permits.
content: IKAST, Denmark — Haitham Kurdi, a 61-year-old asylum seeker from Syria, has been languishing for nearly six months in a deportation center in Denmark, where relatives say he has grown depressed and barely eats. He suffers from tics and has started talking to himself.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: March 7, 2022
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, March 7, 2022.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: New York’s Students Shed Their Masks, Warily, in Pandemic Milestone
description: Not all New York’s students were ready to give up masks, even after Mayor Eric Adams said they could.
content: A kindergartner in Queens wasn’t quite ready to part with his Mickey Mouse masks. On Staten Island, another kindergartner had lost one of his bottom teeth and couldn’t wait to show off his new smile.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: A renewed attack by Russia.
content: Russian forces launched a heavy artillery barrage against the strategic southern Ukrainian port city of Mykolaiv early this morning, a day after Ukrainian troops pushed Russia’s faltering military from the city limits. Residents are facing increasingly dire conditions in another port city, Mariupol, which has been cut off from food, heat and electricity for days. Follow the latest updates here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano and Valerie Hopkins
title: Russia, Blocked From the Global Internet, Plunges Into Digital Isolation
description: Russian authorities and multinational companies have erected a digital barricade between the country and the West, erasing the last remnants of independent information online.
content: Even as President Vladimir V. Putin tightened his grip on Russian society over the past 22 years, small pockets of independent information and political expression remained online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noele Illien
title: Switzerland joined in sanctions, but Russia’s oil, metals and grains still trade there.
description: Swiss authorities estimate that 80% of Russia’s raw materials and resources are exchanged in their country.
content: ZURICH — Swiss officials were applauded last week when they broke with the country’s tradition of neutrality by joining the United States, the European Union and others in imposing sanctions on Russia for its invasion of Ukraine. But there was a large loophole in the joint effort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: As Oil Goes Up, Stocks Go Down
description: Climbing energy prices are roiling markets.
content: The I.M.F. said over the weekend that the war in Ukraine and sanctions against Russia would have a “severe impact” on the global economy, further disrupting supply chains and stoking already high inflation. Investors have been processing the latest developments, and markets opened on Monday with sharp moves: Most notably, energy prices are soaring and stocks are sinking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: proselytize
description: This word has appeared in nine articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word proselytize has appeared in nine articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on June 10 in “How Microsoft Is Ditching the Video Game Console Wars” by Kellen Browning:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford
title: New York City public school children head to their first day of class without masks.
description: Schoolchildren from the Upper East Side to East New York turned up to classrooms on Monday morning with nothing on their faces — except, perhaps, the remnants of a milk mustache.
content: Schoolchildren from the Upper East Side to East New York turned up to classrooms on Monday morning with nothing on their faces — except, perhaps, the remnants of a milk mustache.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Steven Erlanger and Anton Troianovski
title: Russia Keeps Up Attack, Again Halting Evacuation of Ukrainian Port City
description: An encircled Mariupol faced intense shelling, while Russian forces kept up their slow advance on Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — As Russia pursued its war against Ukraine in the face of determined resistance, a planned cease-fire and evacuation of civilians from Mariupol — a port city of a half-million people on Ukraine’s southeastern coast — was halted for a second consecutive day on Sunday amid “intense shelling” by Russian forces that have encircled the city, the mayor’s office said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: ‘Billions’ Season 6, Episode 7 Recap: Let the Games Begin
description: Chuck visits an old friend. Wags tries to cover his boss’s tracks as the decision about New York’s Olympics bid nears.
content: You know, it’s funny: Before I watched this episode of “Billions,” I’d been thinking to myself, “It’s been too long since Chuck Rhoades went to a dungeon.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Felder
title: In Miami Beach, Off the Beaten Track, a Gallery District Beckons
description: Do two galleries make a scene? Their owners hope collectors in search of emerging artists travel beyond the established art communities to Jupiter and Central Fine.
content: MIAMI BEACH — When Gabriel Kilongo decided to leave his job as a sales associate at Mitchell-Innes & Nash to open a gallery of his own in Miami’s booming art scene, he chose a considerably less predictable location than a hub like the Design District or Little Haiti.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caleb Kenna
title: Vermont, Dressed in Snow
description: For a longtime aerial photographer, snowfall in the Green Mountain State offers a fresh palette of possibility.
content: Vermont is famous for its verdant summer landscapes and postcard-worthy fall colors. But it’s the Green Mountain State’s winter landscape that truly sparks my photographic eye.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley
title: Supreme Court Will Not Review Decision to Overturn Bill Cosby’s Conviction
description: Prosecutors had appealed a ruling by the Pennsylvania Supreme Court, which had overturned the conviction on due process grounds.
content: The U.S. Supreme Court has rejected the bid by prosecutors in Pennsylvania to reinstate Bill Cosby’s conviction for sexual assault, a decision that ends the criminal case that had led to imprisonment for the man once known as America’s Dad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Balenciaga Goes Where Fashion Hasn’t Dared Go Before
description: In the show of the season, the brand takes on the war in Ukraine. Valentino embraces love. And Givenchy buckles down.
content: PARIS — In a cold, dark airplane hangar on the edge of Paris, as reports broke of more than 1.5 million refugees fleeing through Europe from Ukraine, Demna, the mononymic designer of Balenciaga who had fled Georgia as a 12-year-old during that country’s civil war, built an enormous snow globe and let loose a storm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: Baltics, in Russia's Shadow, Demand Tougher Stance From West
description: “We have no illusions about Putin’s Russia anymore,” said one Baltic official in a meeting with the U.S. secretary of state.
content: VILNIUS, Lithuania — Demanding assurances that the Baltic States will not become Russia’s next battleground, Lithuania’s president firmly told America’s top diplomat on Monday that warnings to deter Moscow from further aggressions are “no longer enough.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Zagoria
title: Patrick Ewing Needs Another Moment of Glory at the Garden
description: One year after winning the Big East title game to gain an N.C.A.A. tournament berth, Georgetown enters this year’s conference tournament winless in league play.
content: After his Georgetown team lost at Xavier on Saturday night to set a Big East Conference record for futility, a solemn Patrick Ewing walked through the handshake line and shook hands with Xavier Coach Travis Steele, his staff and the Musketeers players.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers
title: With New Limits on Media, Putin Closes a Door on Russia’s ‘Openness’
description: The Russian leader is undoing the social freedoms introduced at the end of the Soviet Union, risking a return to total control and ideological isolation.
content: One of the paradoxical things about Vladimir V. Putin’s increasingly authoritarian rule of Russia was how relatively open society always remained.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gregory Schmidt
title: Deloitte and EY join other big companies exiting Russia.
description: The accounting firms said they would sever ties, after similar announcements from their rivals KPMG and PwC.
content: Deloitte and EY, two of the world’s largest accounting firms, announced on Monday that they would pull out of Russia, joining the other so-called Big Four firms, KPMG International and PwC, which said on Sunday that they would quit the country after its invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tressie McMillan Cottom
title: How to Avoid Drowning in an Ocean of Information
description: Responsible citizens must bear witness to what’s happening in Ukraine. But we have limits.
content: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has made it difficult to focus on anything else. Images of people living below ground to escape missile strikes, families trekking across borders, crying children — they are embedded in my mind. We are rightfully awed by the Ukrainian people’s resolve in the face of an unprovoked attack, a kind of resolve we see people all over the world have shown in the face of violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: De Gustibus, at Macy’s, Returns With In-Person Cooking Classes
description: The cooking school, which features classes from chefs, now has a hybrid schedule with both virtual and in-person courses.
content: De Gustibus, the New York cooking school that features chefs and food personalities, has been going strong in Macy’s Herald Square for some 40 years. Until the pandemic hit, classes were held at the department store in a classroom designed by Miele USA, the appliance company. During the pandemic the classes were virtual and then became hybrid, both in-person and virtual. Now there is a hybrid of in-person sessions in the classroom, and a virtual feed that anyone can watch for a fee. Coming up on the schedule are Michael Lomonaco of Porter House New York and Hudson Yards Grill, on April 6; and Chris Cheung of East Wind Snack Shop, on April 14. Classes at Macy’s start at $135 and include a tasting; virtual classes are $30, $115 with food from the chef shipped to attendees for some sessions; and classes in restaurants are $300.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2 Million Homes in California
description: A ranch house in Los Angeles, a renovated 1963 home in Newport Beach and a hillside bungalow near Berkeley.
content: This house is in the northeast part of the city, a few blocks from Ernest E. Debs Regional Park, where the walking trails offer views of the San Gabriel Mountains and downtown Los Angeles. The neighborhood is quiet, but just a five-minute drive or a 20-minute walk from the popular restaurants and bars on North Figueroa Street, in Highland Park. Pasadena and downtown Los Angeles are about 15 minutes away, as is Occidental College, in Eagle Rock.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing and Eric Lipton
title: Carmakers Race to Control Next-Generation Battery Technology
description: The prize: batteries that would be cheaper, faster to charge and less vulnerable to raw material shortages. Whoever gets there first will have a major advantage.
content: WOBURN, Mass. — Already far behind Asian manufacturers in building electric car batteries, U.S. automakers and their suppliers are racing to develop a new generation of batteries that are cheaper, can pack in more energy and charge faster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maia Szalavitz
title: What the Opioid Crisis Took From People in Pain
description: Opioid prescriptions are down, but overdose deaths remain high, and certain patients have lost relief.
content: Doctors didn’t think Brent Slone would survive his gruesome 2011 car crash. His car flipped after he swerved to avoid a stalled vehicle. His spinal cord was compressed. He broke several ribs, a shoulder and a knee. One lung collapsed. A shattered pelvic bone ruptured his bladder and seriously damaged his spleen, kidney and colon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: The Dreamiest Desserts Start With These Two Flavors
description: Kesar pista, an intoxicating combination of fragrant saffron and earthy pistachio, is a favorite on the Indian subcontinent — and an excellent base for many sweets.
content: In Japan, you can buy Kit Kats that taste like green tea. In Canada, Lay’s potato chips can be ketchup flavored. And now, a kesar pista Snickers bar has arrived in India.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz, Andrew E. Kramer and Rick Gladstone
title: Humanitarian Crisis Worsens for Ukrainians Trapped in Russia’s Onslaught
description: Two weeks after the invasion began, tens of thousands of Ukrainians are without food, water or power. The Russians are increasingly resorting to indiscriminate shelling to help their forces advance.
content: MYKOLAIV, Ukraine — Increasingly indiscriminate Russian shelling that has trapped and traumatized Ukrainian civilians magnified fears on Monday of an intensifying humanitarian crisis that has already left tens of thousands without food, water, power or heat in besieged cities of southern Ukraine and elsewhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon
title: The Staten Island House Where Black History Lives
description: A 90-year-old former schoolteacher’s collection includes Muhammad Ali’s boxing shoes and Tuskegee Airmen headgear — but it also features Ku Klux Klan toys.
content: In Elizabeth Meaders’s dining room, the horrors of slavery are displayed on the table: reward posters for the capture of people fleeing enslavement and the tools — a branding iron, wooden hobbles and a bullwhip — for punishing them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: FIFA Will Allow Foreign Players in Russia to Break Contracts
description: The move announced Monday is temporary, but it will free about 100 players to seek new teams for the rest of the season.
content: A week after declaring that Russian teams cannot play international soccer for an indefinite period because of the country’s invasion of Ukraine, soccer’s governing body announced on Monday that foreign players and coaches contracted by Russian teams can suspend their contracts and move elsewhere — at least temporarily.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Russia escalates attacks on civilians
description: Plus new research warning of a drier Amazon and Xi’s relationship with Putin.
content: Russian forces are stepping up indiscriminate attacks on civilian targets and laying siege to cities across Ukraine. Fears are growing over the fate of thousands of Ukrainians trapped in cities without heat and enough food supplies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor and Christine Chung
title: Shooting Outside Iowa School Leaves 1 Teen Dead and 2 Critically Wounded
description: Potential suspects were in custody after the shooting at East High School in Des Moines, the authorities said.
content: A shooting outside a high school in Des Moines on Monday afternoon left a 15-year-old boy dead and two other teenagers in critical condition in what appeared to have been a drive-by attack, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Ukraine Is a Test We Cannot Fail
description: We need to make it clear to Vladimir Putin that he will never, ever win this war.
content: Gail Collins: Bret, let’s start our look back at the week with President Biden’s State of the Union speech. What do you think? Did he set the right tone on Ukraine? And hey, what about all the domestic stuff?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Says 10 Burglaries Can Count as One Offense
description: The case concerned a federal law that calls for stiff sentences for gun crimes when the defendant had committed three felonies “on occasions different from one another.”
content: In 1997, William Dale Wooden pleaded guilty to 10 counts of burglary, one for each of the adjacent storage units he had broken into in one night. More than a decade later, he was convicted of being a felon in possession of a gun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Lobrano
title: Dior’s New Chef Has Aspirations
description: Chef Jean Imbert’s job is to make the new Dior restaurant the go-to dining spot for the fashion crowd. Here’s how he plans to do it.
content: PARIS — Talk about a new look.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger, Eric Schmitt, Helene Cooper, Julian E. Barnes and Kenneth P. Vogel
title: Arming Ukraine: 17,000 Anti-Tank Weapons in 6 Days and a Clandestine Cybercorps
description: The United States has walked to the edge of direct conflict with Russia in an operation that is reminiscent of the Berlin airlift of 1948-49, but far more complex.
content: On a snowy tarmac at Amari Air Base in northern Estonia on Sunday morning, pallets of rifles, ammunition and other weapons were being loaded onto one of the largest cargo planes in the world, an Antonov AN-124, belonging to the Ukrainian air force. It is an artifact of the Cold War, built and purchased when Ukraine was still part of the Soviet Union.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky
title: A Quebec restaurant credited with inventing poutine rebrands to rebuke Putin (Poutine in French).
description: Protest against the war in Ukraine has a new cultural front — food and drink names — as people across the world show solidarity with Ukraine by renaming or boycotting Russian-made products.
content: MONTREAL — A Quebec restaurant credited with inventing poutine, the beloved trouser-busting dish of French fries, cheese curds and gravy, has decided to rebrand because of what it calls an unfortunate coincidence: President Vladimir V. Putin’s name in French is spelled and pronounced “Poutine.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: How the ‘Encanto’ Soundtrack Became a Smash
description: With its eighth week at No. 1 on Billboard’s album chart, the LP featuring songs from Lin-Manuel Miranda is a lesson in how fans drive hits from social media to streaming services.
content: The soundtrack to Disney’s “Encanto” had an inauspicious start on the Billboard 200 album chart, arriving at No. 197 after the animated film’s release in November, just below Bob Seger’s “Greatest Hits” and a Notorious B.I.G. reissue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: Inside Denmark’s Immigration Centers
description: Here's what I saw in two centers for Syrian asylum seekers in Denmark who had their residency permits stripped.
content: Here's what I saw in two centers for Syrian asylum seekers in Denmark who had their residency permits stripped.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by John Otis
title: How Much Do You Know About Latvia?
description: Can you find Latvia on a map? What else do you know about this European country with about two million people?
content: Can you find Latvia on a map? What else do you know about this European country with about two million people?
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $2 Million in California
description: A ranch house in Los Angeles, a renovated 1963 home in Newport Beach and a hillside bungalow near Berkeley.
content: A ranch house in Los Angeles, a renovated 1963 home in Newport Beach and a hillside bungalow near Berkeley.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Ostrovsky and Emily Rhyne
title: ‘The Worst is Behind You’: Ukrainian Family Reunites in Poland
description: Polish resident Ksenia Kraft reunited with her cousins and their five children near the border with Ukraine. The families fled the town of Berdychiv in central Ukraine after Russia’s invasion.
content: Polish resident Ksenia Kraft reunited with her cousins and their five children near the border with Ukraine. The families fled the town of Berdychiv in central Ukraine after Russia’s invasion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Blinken Seeks to Assure Baltic Allies of Defense From Russia
description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said during a visit to Lithuania that the United States was committed to defending “every inch of NATO territory if it comes under attack.”
content: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said during a visit to Lithuania that the United States was committed to defending “every inch of NATO territory if it comes under attack.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: Two ‘Leftist Bros’ Dive Into Conservatism to ‘Know Your Enemy’
description: The podcast hosted by Matthew Sitman and Sam Adler-Bell offers history lessons that middle-aged liberals, young socialists and even some conservatives can love.
content: When Matthew Sitman and Sam Adler-Bell sat down in the spring of 2019 to start the podcast “Know Your Enemy,” all they had was a microphone, a cheeky title and the vague hope that “yet another podcast where two leftist bros guide you through the swampy morass of the American right,” as they put it, might be something other people would actually listen to.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Have You Had an Experience With ‘Death Cleaning’? Tell Us Your Story.
description: We ask readers about preparing in advance or cleaning a house after the loss of a family member.
content: A Feb. 27 Real Estate article, “The Life-Affirming Comforts of ‘Death Cleaning,’” described how many people are now sorting through the clutter of their own possessions, or that of their parents, to avoid the daunting housecleaning task that family members can face after a death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: 15-Minute Garlic Noodles for the Monday Blues
description: Tuck into J. Kenji López-Alt’s interpretation of the Vietnamese American classic.
content: Good morning. J. Kenji López-Alt is in The Times this week with an excerpt from his latest cookbook, “The Wok: Recipes and Techniques,” out tomorrow. It’s an invaluable guide to using one of the most versatile stovetop implements in the world and, in this particular chapter, provides introduction to a home-cooked version of a Vietnamese American classic. That is: garlic noodles (above), a deeply San Franciscan dish invented in the 1970s by the chef Helene An at the city’s Thanh Long restaurant.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Ukrainian Family Killed While Fleeing
description: “Do we have the courage to stop Vladimir Putin?” a reader asks. Others discuss sanctions and censorship. Also: Pregnant at work; truly seeing; “unbecoming” women.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
